definition:
The [*linear congruence*]{} $$ax\equiv b \pmod{m},$$ where $a$, $b$ and
$m$ are known integers and $\gcd{(a,\,m)} = 1$, has exactly one solution
$x$ in $\mathbb{Z}$, when numbers congruent to each other are not
regarded as different. The solution can be obtained as
$$x = a^{\varphi(m)-1}b,$$ where $\varphi$ means Euler’s phi-function.

Solving the linear congruence also gives the solution of the
[*Diophantine equation*]{} $$ax\!-\!my = b,$$ and conversely. If
$x = x_0$, $y = y_0$ is a solution of this equation, then the general
solution is $$\begin{cases}
x = x_0\!+\!km,\\
y = y_0\!+\!ka,\\
\end{cases}$$ where $k = 0$, $\pm1$, $\pm2$, …
